data.title: Precious piece of history
data.text: This area of homes is exquisite.  It is truly a treasure in Toledo, OH.  I am a Realtor in the Toledo and surrounding areas and have had the pleasure of showing quite a few homes in the area.  It is always breathtaking walking in to these mansions for the first time.  I give so much credit to the homeowners who put their heart and souls in to restoring them to their original grandeur. They have a wonderful festival in early Spring that you can tour certain homes.  A MUST see in Toledo.

data.title: Beautiful spot
data.text: Beautiful architecture and landscaping. Spend some time strolling through, taking in the vistas and the history.

data.title: The little known gem of Toledo
data.text: If you want to experience what historic Toledo was mixed with new art flair, the Old West End is for you. Any month free activities to enjoy with friends and family.

data.title: Historic Gems Will Get me Every Time!
data.text: We stayed with a couple in a completely restored 1895 magnificent home. I am from Detroit (not suburbs) and am both familiar with and comfortable in the mixed neighborhoods. I used mixed to mean every possible take, ethnic, homes of grandeur restored and many yet in need of grandeur restored. I was smitten. It is only one mile to the excellent Toledo Art Museum--just think, walkable! The residents are eclectic, interesting and proud. Here's hoping all the gems can be saved and restored.

data.title: So many stunning homes and tons of history!
data.text: Old West End Fest '16 was a perfect opportunity to come here.  There are so many incredible homes in so many varieties of styles, it's almost unreal.  LOTS of walking as there are MANY blocks of these homes.

data.title: I lived in the Historic Old West End 1997-2000, so here's my two cents worth
data.text: If you like historic architecture and find yourself in Toldeo, the Old West End is definitely worth a walking tour. It has a surprisingly large assortment of stunning, grand, ornate, and distinctly varied Victorian homes. So much history forms the backbone of this old gritty town. Its heyday is long past, but its past is rich. The place I lived in was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.The neighborhood was going through some gentrification when I lived there and the cast of characters I met were quite entertaining, including my next door neighbor. We were both transplants. And we are now married. :) P.S. I clicked a visit date of April 2015 because I was forced to make a choice of dates.

data.title: Great place to live
data.text: We have a festival the first saturday in june that has tours, music, parade, and garage sales with antiques.  they also have tours during christmas time.

data.title: Beautiful historical homes
data.text: Lots to see. Drive through slowly and take in all these giant homes! If you get a chance go back during the holidays and take the homes tour!

data.title: Old West End - beautiful!
data.text: The homes in the Old West End are mainly from the Victorian period.  It is well worth a drive or walk through the beautiful streets.   Every year, during the first weekend in June, is the Old West  End Festival.  A selection of houses are open for touring, there is an art fair, food vendors,  and music.   Also, every year on the first Sunday in December, the "Tours de Noel" are held with homes open for touring, fully decorated for Christmas.

data.title: Beautiful revitalization in a dying city
data.text: This area features some truly unique gems.  The people here have really done a good job preserving many of the architectural gems for this area.  The old west end stands out as an incredible  island of beautiful homes in a city filled with burned out and vacant houses.  This area is worth the visit.  If you want to help support Toledo, stay at the Casey Pomeroy house (in the Vistula District... there is no place to stay in the OWE anymore now that the Mansionview sold to private folks) then take a rour of the OWE.  If you can, schedule it during the "Parade of Homes".  As is well known, Toledo is mini Detroit.  It is a dying post industry city trying to survive.  But this area truly is a remarkable area with mansion after mansion of restored homes with architectural uniqueness that you will not find anywhere else.  Worth the visit.

data.title: History Buffs Would Enjoy This Area
data.text: The Old West End is a grand collection of homes built by the wealthy in the late 1800s and early 1900s. This was the area of the movers and shakers in early Toledo. On the first weekend of June the Old West End Festival is held. One of the homes opened this year was the Edward Drummond Libbey home. He was the founder of Libbey Glass and the Toledo Museum of Art. In front of other homes are historical markers stating who was the original owner. A great place to visit!

data.title: Great for Architecture Buffs
data.text:
This part of Toledo takes up about 25 city blocks north of the Toledo Museum of Art. The area is known for holding the most Victorian, Edwardian and Arts and Crafts homes east of the Mississippi. Much of the construction here took place between 1875 and 1915. Some of the neighborhood has fallen into decay and is a bit sketchy. Part of the neighborhood, however, is a National Historic District with mostly well-maintained houses.

For those interested in this earlier-era architecture, a stroll through some of the Historic District, starting by the art museum, can be rewarding. But It was an extremely hot and humid day when we visited, so we chose to drive slowly along a few of the streets. We gawked at the mostly large homes -- some as big as 10,000 square feet. The houses sat back from the sidewalks, with huge front lawns and little backyard space. Many featured large front porches. Exterior colors varied, ranging from red to gray. We saw no residents during our short period in the neighborhood on a late Friday afternoon.

The neighborhood holds at least two festivals yearly -- one in June and another in December. Attending one would likely be a nice way to get an even better feel for the Old West End.

data.title: A few nice blocks left...
data.text: ...to take a pretty walk.  The homes are beautiful and it's an enjoyable stroll, especially in the springtime.

data.title: One of the Most Interesting Neighborhoods in Toledo
data.text:
The Old West End is an area of Toledo where the old wealthy used to live in the 19th-early 20th century.  

It is the largest collection of historic Victorian homes in the area and consist of beautiful tree lined streets and stately homes.

I have a few relatives who live in OWE and I have always desired to live in the neighborhood myself.  I was VERY upset when my grandma sold her house to someone outside of the family but I am happy that the current owners have made sure that it still looks great on the outside at least.  I wonder about the inside and am tempted to knock on their door to check out the interior lol!  Grandma and I spent many months peeling off old wall paper and refinishing woodwork, moulding, and baseboards in her house back in the 1990s prior to her selling it.

OWE is surrounded by some blighted areas and even outlying parts of OWE itself is blighted.  I know that Toledoans it seems in general like to complain about the city and in many respects I can understand the complaints, but my family has lived in OWE since the late 1960s and when I was a kid in the 1980s, the neighborhood looked worse then than it does now.  It really is a special place and in my opinion of the best centrally located neighborhoods in the city.  There are more businesses now.  It is a more diverse (both ethnically and income-wise) community than it used to be and it seems there is a great community feel between the newer residents and older residents.  

As has been mentioned, the OWE festival in June and the holiday home tours occurring in December are some of the highlights of the neighborhood.  I do think that there should be more guided tours in regards to local history and interesting facts.  Maybe they already have that going on, but if not, it would be great to have at least monthly or bi-monthly walking tours of the neighborhood for those that are interested.  It really is a special, unique community in Toledo.

data.title: Beautiful step back into time!
data.text: We have been to the festivals in the summer and recently Tour Noel a Christmas decorations tour. That tour was too much talk about the house owners possessions and collections. The houses themselves are labors of love and worth visiting the neighborhood for. We stopped by the Black Kite Coffee Shop and loved the charm. There are fees when they have house tours but the summer festival is free.

data.title: Shadows and light
data.text: Proud history, proud residence.. The largest collection of Victorian era craftsmanship east of the Mississippi .. Take the holiday tour and enjoy

data.title: Interesting to drive through
data.text: Its interesting but not worth seeing unless you have a good local guide to explain the homes or during the holiday when there are open houses

data.title: Great Historic Area
data.text: My wife and I go every June to the Old West End Festival and have a great time. So many old historic homes it is spectacular. If you have a desire for garage sales, the festival is the time to go. The area is becoming more gentrified but there are still some sketchy areas that you should avoid but overall an interesting place to visit.

data.title: Festival
data.text: love the tours of the homes and the culture of the neighborhood, they just don't build them like that anymore

data.title: Romantic Stately Old Homes, Wonderful History
data.text: Just love the Old West End Festival every year - to stroll thru the Old West End neighborhoods and imagine what it must've been like to have been an affluent member of Toledo's  society - Many new owners take great pride in their homes with beautifully restored homes and gorgeous landscaping.  There are also many folks selling antiques, vendors with food - even a beer if you like!  Something we look forward to every year!  Gosh can't remember what summer month they have it!!
